metadata.title: BLS Disability Employment Statistics - 2024 Annual Averages
metadata.source: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, Current Population Survey (CPS)
metadata.release_title: Persons with a Disability: Labor Force Characteristics - 2024
notes: Data are from the Current Population Survey (CPS), a monthly survey of about 60,000 households conducted by the U.S. Census Bureau for the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Questions to identify persons with a disability were added to the CPS in June 2008. Annual averages are available starting from 2009.

Persons are classified as having a disability if they have at least one of the following conditions: deaf or serious difficulty hearing; blind or serious difficulty seeing; serious difficulty concentrating, remembering, or making decisions; serious difficulty walking or climbing stairs; difficulty dressing or bathing; difficulty doing errands alone.
Values marked as null could not be verified from publicly accessible search results and should be obtained directly from the BLS report tables.
All percentages are 2024 annual averages unless otherwise noted.
metadata.compiled_from: Web search of published BLS data

population_overview.note: People with a disability accounted for about 13 percent of the civilian noninstitutional population age 16 and over in 2024.

with_disability.note: Half of those with a disability were age 65 and over in 2024.

without_disability.note: About 18 percent of those with no disability were age 65 and over.

notes: Labor force participation rate for people with a disability (24.5%) reached a series high in 2024.
Employment-population ratio for people with a disability (22.7%) was also a series high.
The unemployment rate for people with a disability was about twice that of those with no disability.
Workers with a disability were nearly twice as likely to work part time as workers with no disability.
A larger share of people with a disability were self-employed than were those with no disability.

with_disability.note: Among people with a disability ages 16 to 64, the employment-population ratio was 37.4 percent and the participation rate was 40.7 percent in 2024.

disability_prevalence.note: Percent of each group's population reporting a disability.

unemployment_rate_with_disability.note: Unemployment rates for persons with a disability by race/ethnicity. Jobless rates were higher among Black or African American and Hispanic or Latino persons with a disability.

unemployment_rate_without_disability.note: Specific values by race for persons without disability not extracted from search results. Available in BLS Table 1.

by_sex.note: Women were more likely to have a disability than men, partly reflecting the greater life expectancy of women. In 2023, the unemployment rates were the same for men and women with a disability at 7.2 percent. Specific 2024 sex-disaggregated employment-population ratios and participation rates are available in BLS Table 1 but were not extractable from search results.

reference_2023.source_note: 2023 annual averages; 2024 sex-specific rates available in BLS Table 1.

educational_attainment_distribution.note: About 23 percent of people with a disability had completed a bachelor's degree or higher compared with about 42 percent of those with no disability.

employment_population_ratio.note: For all levels of education, people with a disability were much less likely to be employed than their counterparts with no disability. Specific ratios by education level are in BLS Table 1 but were not fully extractable from search results.

management_professional_and_related.note: People with a disability were much less likely to work in management, professional, and related occupations.

service.note: Workers with a disability were more likely to work in service occupations.

sales_and_office.note: People with a disability were more likely to work in sales and office occupations.

natural_resources_construction_and_maint.note: Workers with a disability were somewhat less likely to work in these occupations.

production_transportation_and_material_m.note: Workers with a disability were more likely to work in production, transportation, and material moving.

retail_trade.note: Retail trade employed 13.1 percent of all workers with a disability, higher than the 10.0 percent of those without.

health_care_and_social_assistance.note: Available in BLS Table 4 but not extractable from search results.

education_services.note: Available in BLS Table 4 but not extractable from search results.

professional_and_business_services.note: Available in BLS Table 4 but not extractable from search results.

by_disability_type.source: Persons with a Disability: Barriers to Employment and Other Labor-Related Issues (BLS USDL-25-1773)
by_disability_type.note: Data are from the July 2024 CPS supplement, not annual averages. Classifications differ from the standard CPS disability questions.

historical_trends.note: Annual averages from BLS Current Population Survey. Disability questions added to CPS in June 2008; first full-year annual averages available for 2009. Historical employment-population ratio data verified from BLS Economics Daily articles and archived news releases. Some years have incomplete data where specific values could not be confirmed from search results.

employment_population_ratio.description: Employment-population ratio for persons with a disability, 16 years and over, annual averages

unemployment_rate.description: Unemployment rate for persons with a disability, 16 years and over, annual averages
unemployment_rate.note: Many annual values could not be confirmed from search results. The FRED series LNU04074597 contains complete monthly and annual data.

labor_force_participation_rate.description: Labor force participation rate for persons with a disability, 16 years and over, annual averages
labor_force_participation_rate.note: Many annual values could not be confirmed from search results. The FRED series LNU01374597 contains complete monthly and annual data. The 2024 value of 24.5% is a series high since data were first reported.

key_findings_2024: People with a disability accounted for about 13 percent of the U.S. civilian noninstitutional population age 16 and over in 2024.
The employment-population ratio for people with a disability was 22.7 percent, a series high, compared with 65.5 percent for those without a disability.
The labor force participation rate for people with a disability reached a series high of 24.5 percent in 2024.
The unemployment rate for people with a disability was 7.5 percent, about twice the 3.8 percent rate for those without a disability.
About 75 percent of people with a disability were not in the labor force, compared with about 32 percent of those without.
About 31 percent of workers with a disability usually worked part time, compared with about 17 percent of workers without a disability.
A larger share of people with a disability were self-employed (9.2 percent) than those without (6.0 percent).

People with a disability were less likely to work in management and professional occupations (37.9 percent vs. 44.1 percent) and more likely to work in service occupations (19.0 percent vs. 16.3 percent).
Retail trade employed 13.1 percent of workers with a disability vs. 10.0 percent of workers without.
Among people with a disability, unemployment rates were highest for Black or African American (10.7 percent) and Hispanic or Latino (9.4 percent) persons.
About 23 percent of people with a disability had completed a bachelor's degree or higher, compared with about 42 percent of those without.
Among people with a disability ages 16 to 64, the employment-population ratio was 37.4 percent.
Half of people with a disability were age 65 and over, compared with about 18 percent of those without.

fully_verified_from_search_results: Overall employment-population ratio, unemployment rate, labor force participation rate (2024)
Race/ethnicity unemployment rates for persons with disability (2024)
Occupation distribution for persons with/without disability (2024)
Industry: retail trade, leisure/hospitality, other services (2024)
Working age (16-64) employment-population ratio and participation rate (2024)
not_available_from_search_results: Sex-specific employment-population ratios, participation rates, and unemployment rates for 2024 (available in BLS Table 1)
Education-level-specific employment-population ratios for 2024 (available in BLS Table 1)
Age-group-specific employment rates for 2024, e.g. 16-24, 25-54, 55-64, 65+ (available in BLS Table 1 and Table A)
Complete industry distribution (available in BLS Table 4)
Many historical unemployment rates and participation rates (available via FRED series)
Historical without-disability comparison values for most years
recommended_data_sources_for_gaps: BLS Table A (2023-2024 comparison by age): https://www.bls.gov/news.release/disabl.a.htm
